The space shuttle Discovery docked with the International Space Station this morning.
Jut before docking, the astronauts piloted the craft into a back flip so that they could photograph the shuttle's underbelly to check for damage.
A chunk of insulating foam broke off during Discovery's liftoff, though it didn't hit the craft, but that's what happened two and a half years ago when a piece of foam hit the Columbia shuttle.
The Columbia later broke apart as in re-entered the Earth's atmosphere.
Now NASA has put future shuttle flights on hold.
Here's NPR's Jon Hamilton.
Cameras caught the chunk of foam tearing away from Discovery's external fuel tank.
That happened Tuesday just before the shuttle left the atmosphere.
Wayne Hale, who's in charge of the mission's management team, told reporters the timing was fortunate.
If this had come off earlier, we think that that would have been really bad.
So it's not acceptable.

Hale said the air was extremely thin by the time the piece broke loose, so it could not have driven the foam into the shuttle with much force, and video appears to show that foam did not strike anything.
Even so, the incident brought back memories of Columbia's demise.
During its launch, a piece of foam punched a 16-inch hole in the leading edge of one wing.
When the craft re-entered the atmosphere days later, it broke apart.
All seven astronauts on board died.
Bill Parsons is the space shuttle's program manager.
He said the ongoing problems with foam left him no choice but to postpone future flights.

You can say that means we're grounded or whatever terminology you want to use, but right now until we understand this problem and until we're ready to say that we've fixed it and we can say that we're safe to go fly, we're not going to go fly.
Parsons said a close inspection of images taken during the launch showed that foam came off of other parts of the fuel tank as well.
Those included an area that had been completely redesigned since the loss of Columbia.
NASA has already spent more than two years and hundreds of millions of dollars trying to prevent foam from breaking away from the fuel tank.
Engineers eliminated foam from the area that caused the Columbia disaster and they've changed the way the foam is applied.
Parsons said NASA will take as much time as necessary to come up with new solutions.
I don't know if that's a month.
I don't know if that's, you know, three months.
I don't know how long that is right now.

When we came away from that, it obviously--we--I personally am disappointed.
